items.title: Canadian snowboarder Mark McMorris cleared for slopestyle after crash
items.summary_auto: Snowboarder Mark McMorris of Canada, a three-time Olympic bronze medallist, said on Friday he had recovered from a recent concussion and received ‌clearance from doctors to compete in the men's slopestyle event at the Milano-Cortina Games.

items.title: A Ukrainian athlete was banned for his helmet. How does the IOC enforce its rules on political statements?
FBI releases suspect description, new details in Nancy Guthrie disappearance
items.summary_auto: Investigators in Arizona want residents near Nancy Guthrie's home to share surveillance footage of suspicious cars or people they may have noticed in the month before she disappeared.

items.title: Cuba is pushed to the brink
items.summary_auto: The New Yorker’s Jon Lee Anderson talks about the energy crisis in Cuba, which has crippled the country and left them at the mercy of the Trump administration.

items.title: Winnipeg man calls for improved patient safety after mother, 94, attacked in hospital
items.summary_auto: A Winnipeg man whose mother, 94, was assaulted by another patient at St. Boniface Hospital says hospitals need to re-evaluate how patients are paired in shared rooms.

items.title: Rural hospitals might buckle under the pressure if measles spread continues: doctor
items.summary_auto: If the measles outbreak continues to get worse, rural health-care facilities in southwestern Manitoba might not have the capacity to house all the sick, according to a Neepawa family physician.

items.title: Bangladesh Nationalist Party wins country's first election since 2024 uprising
items.summary_auto: The Election Commission said Friday the voter turnout in Thursday's election stood at 59.44%. More than 127 million voters were eligible, with almost half of them women and 5 million first-timers.

items.title: Is your water safe? N.B. lab gave outdated answers
items.summary_auto: Thousands of private well owners in New Brunswick may be finding out they've got a problem that will cost hundreds of dollars to fix, now that New Brunswick has aligned its drinking water guidelines with Health Canada. Updates include a 2019 warning that too much manganese can be harmful to children.

items.title: Nova Scotians’ paper health records being trucked to Ontario to be digitized
items.summary_auto: The union representing health-care administrative professionals has filed a grievance over the contracting out of union work.

items.title: This X account looked like it belonged to the Tumbler Ridge shooter. It was a hoax
items.summary_auto: A social media account that some initially believed belonged to the Tumbler Ridge shooter turned out to be a fraud — and even briefly fooled a prominent non-profit organization. Disinformation researchers say spreading false claims can be extremely harmful, especially in the wake of tragedies like mass shootings.

items.title: She won a landmark discrimination case in Canada. An exhibit and play honour her legacy
items.summary_auto: Gloria Baylis, a Black nurse from Barbados, took a Montreal hotel giant to court in the 60s and won. It was the first Canadian case where an institution was found guilty of job discrimination based on race.

items.title: Emerald Fennell's 'Wuthering Heights' is objectively not Wuthering Heights
items.summary_auto: Emerald Fennell liberally reinterprets Emily Brontë's 1847 novel in her new film but seems uninterested — to the point of negligence — in what the beloved British author was trying to say.

items.title: Premier Danielle Smith says she hasn't signed Alberta separatist petition, or any other
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says she has not signed a petition currently gathering signatures to push for a referendum to pull the province out of Confederation.

items.title: Canadian physics professor steps back from job over Epstein questions
items.summary_auto: A highly regarded theoretical physicist has "agreed to pause his working relationship" with the Perimeter Institute in Waterloo, Ont., where he was one of the founding faculty members, over questions about his presence in the Jeffrey Epstein files released by the U.S. government last month. He's one of several Canadian scholars and businesspeople named in the files.

items.title: Hockey agitator: Why American Abbey Murphy continues to frustrate Canada
items.summary_auto: In a 5-0 thrashing of Canada, American forward Abbey Murphy drew not one, not two, but four penalties. She also had three assists. That's the recipe for how 23-year-old Murphy, who hasn't yet turned professional, has been able to frustrate her opponents.

items.title: Company in Alberta to turn cattle manure into natural gas, bury CO2
items.summary_auto: Manure from thousands of southern Alberta cattle will be used to supply renewable natural gas, while at the same time harmful carbon dioxide emissions will be buried, in a first-of-its-kind project.

items.title: Air Transat aims to repatriate all its customers in Cuba within days
Art exhibit celebrates the work of painter killed in Lapu Lapu Day attack
items.summary_auto: When Nadine Kelln and Jenifer Darbellay first learned they were going to get to do an art show together, they were beyond elated. But before it could ever come to fruition, Darbellay was killed in last year's attack on the Lapu Lapu Day street festival in Vancouver. Now, the show will go on in her honour.

items.title: Ottawa needs more data to probe claims of unpaid work at airlines: minister
items.summary_auto: Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu says her department needs more information from air carriers and unions to settle recent allegations of unpaid work in the airline sector.

items.title: Bondi attacks Dems during Epstein testimony
items.summary_auto: U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi attacked Democrats during her fiery House Judiciary Committee testimony as she faced criticism from lawmakers over the Justice Department's handling of the Epstein files.

items.title: Why is the U.S. cutting Cuba off from the rest of the world? | About That
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump is applying severe economic pressure to an already-strained Cuba mired in a food and power crisis. Andrew Chang explains why the U.S. is choosing now to cut off the country's oil supply, and why, for Trump and U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio, it's also personal.

items.title: Ontario police officer cleared in shooting death of First Nation man in makeshift courtroom
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s police watchdog has cleared an officer of any wrongdoing in connection with the shooting death of  a 23-year-old man in Wapekeka First Nation. Here's what we know about the case in the remote Oji-Cree community, which took place in a makeshift courtroom inside a youth centre.
